column1: Will Russia conduct a flight test of an RS-28 Sarmat ICBM before 1 August 2021?
column6: ['Technology', 'Security and Conflict']
Comments: Incremental adjustment for the passage of time.
https://bit.ly/3j4qfUr / https://bit.ly/3BXu8mQ
Not now
I expect to do well on this question, although not as well as cafe.

The test may still happen (or even already has happened, successful or unsuccessful), but it is just a few days left - time to make a few points: how it could happen that the crowd forecast went from almost 100% (I believe 87% was the top) probability to 1%. Let's start with the caveat - it is just my personal opinion and I do not pretend I have a crystal ball.
Down 10% for passage of time. I think I was asleep at the switch for awhile.
Nothing reported in connection with the Navy Day. Still clear as mud, of course, but decreasing further, in part to compensate for the earlier high level of confidence in a “yes” outcome.
Comments: Incremental adjustment down due to passage of time.
Passage of time
Comments: Incremental adjustment down due to passage of time.

Of the three “unique armaments” promised by Putin “in the near future” (https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/putin-just-made-big-promise-russian-military-even-better-weapons-188888), only Sarmat remains to be tested. Zircon and S-500 tests are in the news. On the other hand, only a short time left in this question.

Another missile test, this time I believe Zircon(?) as it was reportedly hypersonic. Two in two months is certainly telling of Russia's desire to show off their arsenal; however, with so little time to go I actually thinks this lowers my probability rather than raises it.

Down 30% for passage of time. The hypersonic aspect (delayed or not wanted to be displayed) makes sense; the SS-18 update not so certain. RU has plenty of nukes with multiple delivery platforms. They don't need to send any "message" although sometimes it appears they do.
Error
Chest beating continues which probably takes more time to play out.
Going to zero.

Comments: Aggressive messaging continues. Incremental adjustment down due to time constraint. Insider, 07/15/21, 'With close military encounters on opposite sides of the world, Russia is sending a message to the West': https://www.businessinsider.com/close-military-encounters-are-message-from-russia-to-the-west-2021-7 The Sun, 07/15/21, 'PUTIN ON THE BLITZ Russia boasts of ‘most modernised military arsenal in the world’ after intercepting US warplanes as NATO tensions mount': https://www.the-sun.com/news/3288595/russia-boasts-most-modernised-military-arsenal-world/
https://t.me/warbolts/528 https://t.me/warbolts/530
Passage of time.
Down with time and the crowd.
Down 20% for passage of time.
passage of time
passage of time
Time passage
Comments: See @yagudin link about recent ICBM test launch. Design bureau/manufacturer different from Sarmat. Reducing probability by 50% due to time constraints.
Decreasing incrementally

Russia tries its best to normalize relation with the West right now, because in case it is not successfull in that effort, and relations deteriorate, it will become 100% dependent on China in every regard except food, oil/gas and raw resrouces.
Updating downwards, as time passes.
Decreasing due to passing of time.
Time is passing by with a month left.

- https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11736413 — head of the rocket factory restates plans to test Sarmat in Q3 - http://kremlin.ru/events/president/news/65942 — Putin mentions that Sarmat is coming soon - https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/4878133 — another ICBM was successfully tested in mid-June

Relevant primarily because of the timing/reporting issues: FTA: Russia successfully test launches new intercontinental ballistic missile -TASS cites source “The launch took place in mid-June, the source said.” https://www.euronews.com/2021/06/28/us-russia-missile <—Reported by TASS on June 28. The source doesn’t specify which IBM, although a launch test and flight test may be different for our purposes anyway(?). Plesetsk is also the expected site for Sarmat’s launch (and for several other missiles). So: (A) there’s obviously activity on site. Does this make the promised flight test more likely? Boots on the ground, prep underway? (B) Will it be reported as it happens, or only after the fact, and only if successful? (C) Is between now and end of this question enough time? Points B and C make me move a little closer to the crowd forecast.
Down 10% for passage of time.

- 20% → 12% per @Zauchka suggesting that MoD might not report an unsuccessful test. - 12% → 15% per @probahilliby highlighting a successful launch of "_long-delayed_ next-generation ocean reconnaissance system."
I.

Mentions of Sarmat in the media (in Russian), but actually nothing new. Just restating Q3 as a target period: https://ngs24.ru/text/gorod/2021/06/24/69988022/ https://военное.рф/2021/Дайджест22/ https://dela.ru/news/267973/

Moving up slightly with more declarations of a test in "Q3 this year" (where this question sits on a knife edge) and remembering that Met will rapidly degrade in the later parts of Q3 (making trials more weather dependant and "at risk), Putin's popularity slipping slightly (https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russias-putin-tries-give-ruling-party-pre-election-boost-with-spending-promises-2021-06-19/) and a number of interesting political events coming up in the next month or two that would make a successful test flight a popularity bung for the diminutive tsar to want to chase for the "national pride" vote.

Russian media are reporting an unusual cloud over several areas up North that could be a trail left by an ICBM. https://life.ru/p/1405410 https://astrakhan-24.ru/news/misc/v_nebe_nad_astrakhanju_byl_zamechen_sled_ballisticheskoj_rakety_75790 While Sarmat is mentioned among the speculations, Topol-M is also (and possibly more) likely. There’s no reason to think the first flight test will be reported in the media immediately, especially if unsuccessful—or anytime prior to the launch. It could be reported at the most opportune time. (Putin’s annual televised call-in program? That’s June 30. Duma elections? That’s 19 September. Successful conclusion of all three flight tests? That’s ??? Maybe never?)

Possible between July and October, preferably near the election because that's when Russia historically does them. Now that brings up the possibility of being humiliated if a failure were to occur. But then again, they conducted many other tests before the one to come, so perhaps they have the confidence that it will be a success and they are just playing with it at this point. As for the argument regarding Russia's friendly reputation following the summit, here are my thoughts: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1296950
Time
Updating slightly downwards, as time passes.
passage of time and positive summit
Better to try and fail than not to try.
A test so soon after the bilateral meeting would not send a friendly message.
Closer and closer. Reports are that there are exercises on the road-mobile ICBMs, but no evidence yet that the RS-28 will be tested by August.
Time running out
https://prmira.ru/news/poyavilas-informacziya-o-zabastovke-na-krasmashe/
continuing to lower with time
Lowering due to passage of time and US-Russia meeting this past week

The optimal time for showmanship is (nearly?) over, so lowering again. Only one mention of RS-28 that I could find in the news: a popular tabloid MK says Biden was forced to call the summit in the face of new and formidable Russian arsenal, such as Sarmat. Biden would never admit this, however (according to MK), because it would cause psychological stress in the US to go through the roof. Which makes me think Sarmat, with all the publicity the Russian media work up around it, is great as a bogeyman. It will not serve this role very well if it starts failing tests. In other words, Russia would not test Sarmat unless they’re sure it will pass with flying colours—or unless they are sure they can present it that way.
Lower once July 1 arrives. There is Russian activity even near American territories despite the Biden-Putin summit. That tells me the military side may be separate from the political side.
Raising a bit more on the potential of showmanship around the Biden-Putin summit. Will swing back if nothing happens by the end of the week.

The Russian news agency, Tass, writes "the first launch of the Sarmat ICBM within the framework of flight development tests will be carried out tentatively in the third quarter of 2021." Before August 1, 2021 would be the first third of that quarter which already puts the probability at 33% if we assume there is a 100% chance they test it in the third quarter and that the probability of testing it at any time is uniform.
lowering with time

Information field is murky, as is always the case related to the Russian military. This article says a full flight test will take place “no later than” 11 June: https://topcor.ru/20280-istochnik-polnocennyj-pusk-sarmata-provedut-v-blizhajshie-dni.html Of course, 11 June has come and gone with no official announcement of the test. Did it happen and is awaiting a more opportune time to get an announcement? Did it happen and fail? Did it succumb to yet another delay? Another source mentions a worker strike at a factory producing “Sarmat”: https://tayga.info/168482 However, workers are expected to be paid once “Sarmat” is delivered. Raising temporary. Note to self to check the news feed more frequently.
Moving down as time passes

After the chatfest with Biden, Vlad the Shirtless will feel the need to flex something or other in public. The pressure will be on his folks for a successful test, but this Q doesn't require success. Coming up slightly. on the off-chance that this is the display he'll select for the occasion.
Down. 10% for passage of time.
Moving down as time passes
https://www.defensenews.com/air/2021/06/07/putin-confirms-russian-exit-from-open-skies-treaty/
Miss clicked over correction. Bloody slider...
Dropping with passage of time.

Back down because the close proximity to the Biden meeting does not make sense. Additionally, it was once said that 5 tests were scheduled for 2020. That means one test every 2 to 3 months, which is eerily close to an annual quarter. So now it starts to make sense why they are saying the first test will occur during the first quarter. It may require them 2 to 3 months, on average, to produce a single test. Now the question is, will they prefer the test to be in the first, middle, or last part of the third quarter if at all.

A space launch from Plesetsk Cosmodrome has taken place recently, signaling that there is activity there. I found out that there are two launch silos active on the base, and that all three ICBM tests will come from one or both of these origins. We do know that the first is 'tentatively' scheduled to be in the third quarter, and one of the other two will test the full range of the ICBM. We must factor in the time it will take to reload the silo(s) with another ICBM(s). We still need to know whether these test launches are to be fired in relative proximity to each other, and what happened to the other two tests that are no longer planned.
Starting to look like not going to happen.
Following @probahilliby's analysis [1], and especially news updates [2][3].

Comments: Good points @lsgold7, especially in light of recent move by Putin. RFE, 06/07/21, 'Russia Officially Pulls Out Of Open Skies Treaty': https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-open-skies-treaty/31294144.html
Now they are saying it WILL definitely start THIS year. Hmmm...
Just before or after Geneva Summit. Testing new weapons has no downside.

Dropping further a bit. Only one new item in the Russian news in the past week that’s worth mentioning. According to Interfax.ru, deputy PM Yuri Borisov assured the journalists that “everything’s going according to the plan” and the flight tests will “definitely” start this year. Vague verbiage and assurances like this make me skeptical, especially as summer in the North is short (which may or may not be a material obstacle) and our deadline of 1 August is drawing near. OTOH, I should probably try to find out if they’ve actually ever given specific dates ahead of such tests in the past or simply announced after the fact. https://www.interfax.ru/russia/770594

Back up to be around the base rate of one third of the third quarter being in the forecast period. I also found the following information where it says testing is scheduled to be in the northwestern part of Russia. My first thought is COLD COLD COLD! So doing it in the summer when it's warmer is always a good idea. Average humidity via Weather Spark will be relatively high around the time which may influence the frequency of aborts. And the wind is relatively below normal around this time through August - kind of optimal but then again, the wind is probably negligible unless we're talking winter storms and higher-level winds that can cause wind shear on the rocket. Note, I did not include the climate for the rocket launch site(s) but rather the target area.
Comments: Entering 1st week of the 3rd quarter. Adjusting down 30% due to time constraint.
Dropping to 5%, especially with the Biden-Putin summit.

Biden and Putin are supposed to meet on June 16. Putin has an incentive to either conduct the test before the meeting or soon thereafter. However, the announcement made months ago stated the test was to be conducted in the 3rd quarter. That makes July the relevant month for this question although the test could easily fall into August or September and be consistent with their announcement. There is also the possibility that it happens before the 3rd quarter in the time right after their meeting (last 2 weeks in June). That totals a period of 6 weeks. I'm betting that Putin conducts the test soon after the summit and before August 1st.

I am starting to incorporate the Putin-Biden summit into my thinking (gives less odds of this question resolving YES). I find it unlikely . . . <10% . . . that Russia would do such a test around this time due to the summit. So, let's assume now till summit is unviable. Let's add a full week after the summit until things start to get viable again. That leaves us with only 18% of the time left to the year's end and 30% of the time left until the end of the 3rd quarter as stated by some articles here.
https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11307631 Russian sources report the first of the three flight tests planned for 2021 is expected in Q3.
Dropping with the passage of time.

Nothing new on Sarmat even after the Victory Day celebrations. The focus currently seems to be on the failed Kalibr test (https://defence-blog.com/news/russian-navy-weapon-test-ended-in-failure-after-cruise-missile-failed.html, https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9526021/Russian-frigate-narrowly-avoids-blasting-cruise-missile-failed-weapon-test.html) and the "final" Zircon test (https://ria.ru/20210512/rakety-1732016988.html).
August is getting closer...gonna downgrade just a bit, but I think there's still a good chance.

https://www.autoevolution.com/news/russias-fierce-sarmat-missile-closer-to-deployment-with-three-tests-this-year-160966.html First test likely Q3. Since the time frame of the question covers one third of Q3, maybe 33%, but I think the end of Q3 is more likely than the beginning. I'm at about 20% but compensating for an earlier higher forecast.

The first test has been announced by the Russians to take place in the 3rd quarter of 2021 (July, August and September). Only a third of this period is in the question window, so I think it's fair to give this a one-third chance.
I'm going to tenatively say that Russia is full of baloney.

Comments: A lot of hardware on display during the dress rehearsal, both tactical and strategic (RS-24 Yars). A successful Sarmat launch would be a nice touch, in contrast to the aborted Minuteman III launch a couple of days ago. Affirming forecast. Daily Mail, 05/07/21, 'Putin’s glamorous troops prepare alongside Russia’s deadliest weaponry in Moscow’s Red Square as they rehearse for Sunday’s WW2 Victory Day parade': https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9554265/Putins-glamorous-troops-rehearse-Sundays-WW2-Victory-Day-parade.html Air Force Times, 05/05/21, 'Air Force aborts test launch of unarmed Minuteman III nuclear missile': https://www.airforcetimes.com/news/your-air-force/2021/05/05/air-force-aborts-test-launch-of-unarmed-minuteman-iii-nuclear-missile/

Comments: Good comments by @Zauchka and @Greyowlsova. On track to start lowering my probability after May 9. Affirming forecast. TASS, 05/04/21, 'Russia to hold three test launches of its newest Sarmat ICBM this year — source': https://tass.com/defense/1286447

Russian sources report the first of the three flight tests planned for 2021 is expected in Q3. Meaning, it could be after the 1 August resolution date for this question. Chances of delays and unreliability of Russian news sources are also sth to consider. https://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/11307631

So, here we go again. "Sources" in Russian military-industrial complex told TASS that it will be 3 launches in 2021 and one of them will be in the 3rd quarter. All of them will be launched from Plesetsk (near Arkhangelsk, Northwest of Russia) to Kura (on Kamchatka, far Northeast.) LONG flight.
Moving up a little in confidence in "capability" with well identified post from @Zauchka (with thanks!).
Up 35% following @Jzaucha post below.

Moving up. This project has been plagued by delays, but it appears the testing ground has been completed (see below). Still planned for this summer, following successful recent tests elsewhere of the modernized arsenal (eg in Kazakhstan; a torpedo in the Arctic) and a failed cruise missile launch near Vladivostok. Overall, lots of activity. Not sure if it means Sarmat is more or less likely. https://thebulletin.org/premium/2021-03/nuclear-notebook-russian-nuclear-weapons-2021/ “Russia is also developing the heavy SS-29, or Sarmat (RS-28), which will begin replacing the SS-18 (RS-20V) at Uzhur in 2021 or 2022. Three ejection tests were conducted in December 2017, March 2018, and May 2018 at the Plesetsk Space Center, involving cold launch and test firing of the Sarmat’s first stage and booster engine. These tests were originally scheduled for 2016 but were delayed because of difficulties that appeared during the missile’s strength tests. The closing test stages, which will include a test launch with the 62nd Missile Division at Uzhur, was supposed to be completed by the end of 2020; however, this has been delayed, likely due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. In December 2020, Defense Minister Shoigu suggested that Sarmat flight tests would take place during the summer of 2021 at the new Severo-Yeniseysky proving ground (Russian Federation 2020a). Following the success of these tests, Sarmat will officially be handed over to the military and serial production will begin. As of March 2020, Sarmat’s industrial production line has apparently completed all the necessary upgrades to prepare for serial production, which is expected to begin in 2021, barring any unforeseen delays (TASS 2020c; Safronov and Nikolsky 2019).“

If you believe Putin, Sarmat should be fully deployed by “the end of 2022”. Start of flight tests (5 in total) still planned for 2021. But 1 August is a lot nearer now and the statements are still nebulous. https://anna-news.info/raketnyj-kompleks-sarmat-zastupit-na-boevoe-dezhurstvo-v-2022-godu/
Down 50% thanks to @Greyowlsova post below.

Many of Russia's claims have proven to be propaganda/hype. With any weapons platform development, there are/will be, delays. The potential for a flight test in November 2021 is far better than before August 1st 2021.

Actually l intended to decrease my forecast more drastically. As Putin has been talking about Sarmat deployment for a few years now, the propaganda loss of unsuccessful launch increased, l surmise. So the 1st launch should be successful, which means later flight tests.
The deployment of Sarmats was moved to the end of 2022, clear sign they are having troubles.

Comments: Very important observance coming up, May 9. Expect to downgrade my probability if no test flight by this date. Defense Blog, 04/10/21, 'Russia deploys Iskander systems with extended-range missiles to Ukrainian border': https://defence-blog.com/news/army/russia-deploys-iskander-systems-with-extended-range-missiles-to-ukrainian-border.html Defense World, 04/03/21, 'Russia to Develop Kedr New Gen Intercontinental Ballistic Missile from 2023': https://www.defenseworld.net/news/29268/Russia_to_Develop_Kedr_New_Gen_Intercontinental_Ballistic_Missile_from_2023#.YHnT92dKjIU 'On March 1, a source in the space industry had revealed to TASS that Russian defense companies had launched engineering drafting work on the new-generation Kedr ICBM.' TASS, 03/19/21, 'Kremlin says Victory Day Parade to take place on Moscow’s Red Square as usual': https://tass.com/defense/1267985
No positive news for the launch. Time to start decreasing chances for Sarmat flight tests...

Comments: Economy stabilizing. Modernization of strategic nuclear forces appear on track. Affirming forecast. BNE Intellinews, 04/01/21, 'Russia Country Report Apr21 - April, 2021': https://www.intellinews.com/reports/russia-country-report-apr21-april-2021-71516/ Real Clear Defense, 02/20/21, 'Russian Modernization of its Nuclear and Military Forces in 2021': https://www.realcleardefense.com/articles/2021/02/20/russian_modernization_of_its_nuclear_and_military_forces_in_2021_661111.html#:~:text=The%20increase%20in%20strategic%20nuclear,the%20standards%20of%20recent%20years. Clips from RC Defense article: 'Russian Strategic Nuclear Modernization According to President Putin, “…our Army and, most importantly, our nuclear triad have reached the level that guarantees Russia’s security.” He said that modernization of the strategic nuclear forces had reached 86% and that it would increase to 88.3% by the end of 2021.'

While the sample size is low, it seems Russia likes to test rockets not earlier than mid August and no later than January or February, essentially favoring the winter months. This would be somewhat consistent with the public goal of being in service in 2022.

Let's say it takes a reasonable 6 months to complete the first flight test after finishing the facilities (the latter of which reportedly happened within the last few weeks). Let's assume 6 months is the average time it takes and assign it 50% probability in 6 months. 3.8 months left divided by 6 months average is 63%. That's approx 63% to average, or 32%. Cut this in half because it seems they would need to test the rocket engines first before trying to launch a test flight; it appears they have not tested the second and third stage engines publicly. Misc.: They tested ejection systems in 2018. It takes SpaceX 1 to 2 years to assemble one of their rockets. . . .

Increasing on a survey of Google news in Russian. Two regions have facilities equipped for flight tests of this scale and one of them seems to be preparing to flight test Sarmat “in the near future”. https://ngs24.ru/text/world/2021/03/31/69840584/ The Russian media are watching closely what Western journalists and experts say about the ICBM, so it all points to some progress. Also, the area for tests is in the North and the weather there will be unreliable after August.
(no change) This makes interesting reading:
Up a little based on rationale from @Greyowlsova.

Comments: Consider RD-171MV performance models RD-263 (Sarmat) design. Affirming forecast. ARS Technica, 04/02/21, 'Rocket Report: SpaceX readies Super Heavy, Russia tests new engine': https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/04/rocket-report-scottish-spaceport-hits-roadblock-launcher-moves-to-la/ Clips from ARS article: 'Russia is testing the RD-171MV engine. Roscosmos said at the end of March that the advanced LOX-kerosene engine completed a run of eight test-fires. The cycle of test-firings, which occurred over a period of three months, were successful and confirmed the operability of the engine, the Russian space corporation said. Replacing the Proton ... Now, the RD-171MV engine will be delivered to the Progress Rocket and Space Center, where it will eventually undergo integration tests with the first stage of the Soyuz-5 rocket. This rocket, with a capacity of 18 metric tons to low Earth orbit, is conceived of as a replacement for the Proton vehicle and may make its debut in 2023.' Related: NPO Energomash: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NPO_Energomash
Up 10% following @Greyowlsova post below.

Two people on top, Krivoruchko, deputy defense minister, and Rogozin, head of Roskosmos, which makes Sarmats, promised flight tests "in the nearest future". That significantly ups the possibility as I think - "the nearest future" is well within 4 months remaining.

I have been quite pessimistic about the flight test of Sarmat: 1. Using this missile with Avangard supersonic platform sounded unrealistic. 2. In February Russians announced that they would be building a special testing range for Sarmat from scratch in Krasnoyarsk area - beginning with roads and claiming the area from taiga, not an easy task.
Conducting a test would be a way to signal and probe the new U.S. Administration.

More tests will need to occur this year before the RS-28 Sarmat ICBM is scheduled to enter combat service in 2022. The economy is starting to recover and COVID-19 cases declining it seems likely that Russia will have the ability to complete the test this year. Additionally, while the outcome of the parliamentary election in September is unlikely to change, a show of force by testing this ICBM may help shore up confidence in Putin's administration.

The tests have been delayed but due to the operational time proposed for service, a test must be conducted soon. Additionally, there are many ongoing events that may push Putin to test to gain political advantage within the next few months
Russia usually conducts tests twice a year. According to the CSIS it is said to be operational this year.

Comments: See tensions escalating between USA and RU. Putin may expedite a launch to trigger a reset. Affirming forecast. Newsweek, 03/23/21, 'China, Russia, North Korea, Iran Build Ties as U.N. Friends Feud with U.S.': https://www.newsweek.com/china-russia-north-korea-iran-build-ties-un-friends-feud-us-1578169 Politico, 03/20/21, 'Austin hints India’s purchase of Russian missile system could trigger sanctions': https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/20/lloyd-austin-india-sanctions-s400-missile-477304

Officials say it will enter service with Russia's Strategic Missile Forces in 2022. Mass production supposed to start this year. Testing was supposed to finish last year. Multiple official declarations about 'imminent testing in 2021'. Likely that testing occurs
If they were able to they would have done ist. If they do, test will be successful, otherwise they loose their faces
To have many tests planned then pull a 180 may mean something more serious enough for a delay and/or could mean this launch is not urgent. Also...
https://eurasiantimes.com/beware-us-russia-speeds-up-the-development-of-avangard-missile/

Comments: Overall RU modernization efforts advance, although at a slower pace. Here's a thought: 5 flight tests were planned for 2020, with none occurring. Were technical problems being addressed or did the Russians delay flight tests until after the result of the US Presidential election was known? Just speculating..... Affirming forecast. Hot Cars, 03/14/21, 'A Detailed Look At The Kirov-Class Battlecruiser': https://www.hotcars.com/kirov-class-battlecruiser-detailed-look/ Clip from Hot Cars article: 'As of April 2020, the Russian Navy is strongly considering decommission two of the four Kirov-Class cruisers in favor of an ambitious upgrade program for the remaining two. Pyotr Velikiy (Peter The Great) and Admiral Nakhimov, the two newer ships, would be upgraded and have their capabilities greatly enhanced, while the Admiral Ushakov and Admiral Lazarev, the older two ships, would face decommissioning.' The Daily Mail, 03/11/21, 'Japan scrambles F-15 fighter jets to intercept two Russian nuclear-capable Tupolev bombers flying over the Sea of Japan and the Pacific': https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9350365/Japan-scrambles-F-15-fighter-jets-intercept-two-Russian-nuclear-capable-Tupolev-bombers.html Defense World, 03/10/21, 'Russian Tu-160M Bomber with New Engines Completes Factory Tests': https://www.defenseworld.net/news/29121/Russian_Tu_160M_Bomber_with_New_Engines_Completes_Factory_Tests#.YE5bXmhKjIU National Interest, 03/09/21, 'Russia Is Set to Built Two New Nuclear-powered Submarines': https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/russia-set-built-two-new-nuclear-powered-submarines-179667';; Clip from NI article: 'As it stands now, many of Russia’s submarines can best be described as antiquated Soviet-era vessels, and those are still carrying a major part of the burden. However, Russia is well underway in modernizing and upgrading its submarine fleet.' The Jamestown Foundation, 01/13/21, 'Year 2020 in Review: Results of Russia’s Nuclear Weapons Modernization': https://jamestown.org/program/year-2020-in-review-results-of-russias-nuclear-weapons-modernization/ Clip from Jamestown article: 'Management and technical issues, compounded by last year’s coronavirus restrictions and accompanying delays, had relatively little impact on the overall growth of advanced weapons in the nuclear triad. According to previous planning, the share of advanced weapons in the nuclear triad was supposed to increase from 82 to 87 percent by the end of 2020 (RIA Novosti, March 25, 2020), and according to official data, that share reached 86 percent by last December. On the other hand, the coronavirus had a much greater negative effect on the testing of weapons under development. Because of this, the impact of the pandemic will be quite long lasting. Already, the Ministry of Defense’s planning has become more modest: by the end of 2021, it projects a further increase in the share of the latest nuclear weapons by only 2 percent (Kremlin, December 21, 2020).'
https://missilethreat.csis.org/russia-to-deploy-sarmat-icbm-in-2021/

Escalating incentive to "show metal" with B1 Bombers deployed to Norway for arctic defence demonstrations [1] in the face of increasing Russian interest in petrochemical expansion (Russia's fundamental economic crutch).

Comments: IR test-launched new payload carrier. Second Minuteman III test in the last 180 days. PRC upgrading it's land-based component. New DPRK ICBM unveiled last fall. Washington AND Moscow are sure to be watching all advances closely. Sarmat (and/or DPRK) test(s) could prompt Biden/Putin summit sooner than later. Affirming forecast. Comments: 'Does not change the fact that they consider each other an enemy' USA has appeared to have recently tested/deployed all three components of it's [nuclear] Triad. RU, two (air and sea). Affirming forecast. The Daily Sabah, 02/14/21, 'Expectations from START treaty as US, Russia recommit': https://www.dailysabah.com/world/expectations-from-start-treaty-as-us-russia-recommit/news Clips from Sabah article: 'Without hindering the creation of new missile systems, the treaty limits the number of nuclear weapons in use and obliges each side to show each other new weapons before putting them into service, providing necessary transparency, Litovkin said.' '"Nevertheless, both the Pentagon and the Russian General Staff wanted to extend this agreement, but for different reasons. The U.S. cares about maintaining the verification regime – mutual on-site inspections of nuclear carriers, exchange of telemetry of test missiles launches and other sensitive information. Our General Staff is interested in extending New START because, without it, the Americans can deploy additional nuclear carriers in a short time," he said. Although both sides want transparency, that does not change the fact that they consider each other an enemy. "Not that they are going to fight – they are not, but they are ready to balance on the brink of war," Felgengauer said. Another problem is that the treaty is signed only for five years and does not provide for a further extension. "And it is not even clear whether it will last all these five years, because any of the parties can denounce it at any time, and the parties have lots of mutual claims. "In particular, the U.S. insists on involving China, but there are other nuclear-armed countries. Then you need to bring them to negotiations as well. But given the difficulties that existed with the extension of the New START, signed between only two countries, the preparation and signing of another arms control agreement in just five years and between many countries seems almost unrealistic," Felgengauer said. Although the system has reportedly been delayed in coming online, Putin himself is now saying it is entering its final stages of development, and the deputy minister of defense is saying that testing is imminent. While the wording allows for some significant squishiness in terms of specific timing, nobody wants the big bosses to look bad. I estimate that they'll be doing everything in their power to get at least one test done as soon as possible. That said, if the test were a failure, it'd be a disaster on the international stage, so look for the Russians to do everything possible to make sure the first one is a success, even if it means delaying longer.

Putin and defense officials are claiming the RS-28 Sarmat is in the final stages of production and will be ready for tests soon. However, there has been no solid evidence provided and no test dates are currently scheduled. Russia will likely continue to delay tests until it is certain that the RS-28 Sarmat will succeed due to the reputational damage that would be inflicted by a failed test. The Russian Deputy Defense Minister also indicated the ICBM may be covered under New START which will be extended shortly. This could be a face saving measure if development is not going well. Overall, more concrete dates or evidence are needed before I increase my forecast.
Initial forecast is for 50% probability.

Initial forecast, just slightly above consensus. There is whether it is needed or wanted, perhaps for non-technical reasons. In the latter category, I might expect less than normal RDT&E. The whole notion of another nuclear arms race is something the presumed nuclear powers might wish to de-emphasize. Since Russia has a significantly diverse capability, worrying about one system is less important than in the past. Testing means signatures which have to be weighed against benefits.
